H0.text: Atoms are the smallest particles of matter.

H1.text: Ions are the smallest particles of matter.

H2.text: Molecules are the smallest particles of matter.

H3.text: Electrons are the smallest particles of matter.

A4.text: Though the word atom originally denoted a particle that cannot be cut into smaller particles, in modern scientific usage the atom is composed of various subatomic particles.

A5.text: The electron is the least massive of these particles by four orders of magnitude at 9.11×10−31 kg, with a negative electrical charge and a size that is too small to be measured using available techniques.

A6.text: An Atom is a still smaller particle produced by division of a molecule.

A7.text: Protons and neutrons however are not indivisible: they can be divided into quarks.
